    Prepare for PSUT analysis

    Matthew Kuperus Heun

    2019-04-06

    prep_psut.Rmd

    Introduction

    After loading IEA data and ensuring that the data are balanced (see the vignette about loading data) and specifying many of the flows (see the vignette about specifying flows), the analyst can prepare for physical supply-use table (PSUT) analysis of an energy conversion chain. This vignette shows how to use the functions in the IEATools package for that purpose.

    Adding PSUT matrix names (add_psut_matnames())

    The first step to converting the IEA extended energy balance data into PSUT matrices is identifying the matrix in which each datum belongs. The add_psut_matnames() function performs this task. It adds a column named “matname” (by default but changeable by the user) that contains one of R, U, V, or Y to identify the Resources, Use, Make, or Final demand matrix.

    load_tidy_iea_df() %>% 
  add_psut_matnames() %>%
  glimpse()
#> Observations: 399
#> Variables: 12
#> $ Method                 <chr> "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM",…
#> $ Last.stage             <chr> "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final", "Fina…
#> $ Country                <chr> "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA",…
#> $ Year                   <dbl> 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971,…
#> $ Ledger.side            <chr> "Supply", "Supply", "Supply", "Supply", "…
#> $ Flow.aggregation.point <chr> "Total primary energy supply", "Total pri…
#> $ Energy.type            <chr> "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "…
#> $ Unit                   <chr> "ktoe", "ktoe", "ktoe", "ktoe", "ktoe", "…
#> $ Flow                   <chr> "Production", "Production", "Imports", "I…
#> $ Product                <chr> "Primary solid biofuels", "Hydro", "Crude…
#> $ E.dot                  <dbl> 2088, 250, 916, 1, 21, 1, 18, -4, -4, -17…
#> $ matname                <chr> "R", "R", "V", "V", "V", "V", "V", "Y", "…

    Add matrix metadata (add_row_col_meta())

    The next step is to add information to identify the rows and columns for each datum. The add_row_col_meta() function performs this task by adding rowname, colname, rowtype, and coltype columns which identify the names and types of rows and columns in the PSUT matrices. add_row_col_meta() should be called after calling add_psut_matnames(), because it relies on the the matname column to determine names and types.

    load_tidy_iea_df() %>% 
  add_psut_matnames() %>%
  add_row_col_meta() %>% 
  glimpse()
#> Observations: 399
#> Variables: 16
#> $ Method                 <chr> "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM",…
#> $ Last.stage             <chr> "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final", "Fina…
#> $ Country                <chr> "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA",…
#> $ Year                   <dbl> 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971,…
#> $ Ledger.side            <chr> "Supply", "Supply", "Supply", "Supply", "…
#> $ Flow.aggregation.point <chr> "Total primary energy supply", "Total pri…
#> $ Energy.type            <chr> "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "…
#> $ Unit                   <chr> "ktoe", "ktoe", "ktoe", "ktoe", "ktoe", "…
#> $ Flow                   <chr> "Production", "Production", "Imports", "I…
#> $ Product                <chr> "Primary solid biofuels", "Hydro", "Crude…
#> $ E.dot                  <dbl> 2088, 250, 916, 1, 21, 1, 18, -4, -4, -17…
#> $ matname                <chr> "R", "R", "V", "V", "V", "V", "V", "Y", "…
#> $ rowname                <chr> "Production", "Production", "Imports", "I…
#> $ colname                <chr> "Primary solid biofuels", "Hydro", "Crude…
#> $ rowtype                <chr> "Industry", "Industry", "Industry", "Indu…
#> $ coltype                <chr> "Product", "Product", "Product", "Product…

    Collapse to matrices (collapse_to_tidy_psut())

    After identifying row and column names and types, the next step is to collapse the data into PSUT matrices. The collapse_to_tidy_psut() function performs this task using the matsindf::collapse_to_matrices() function internally. The matval column is added to the data frame and contains a matrix for each set of grouping variables which are specified in the grouping_vars argument. collapse_to_tidy_psut() ensures that all entries in each matrix are non-negative.

    Tidy_PSUT <- 
load_tidy_iea_df() %>% 
  specify_all() %>% 
  add_psut_matnames() %>% 
  add_row_col_meta() %>% 
  collapse_to_tidy_psut()
Tidy_PSUT %>% 
  glimpse()
#> Observations: 20
#> Variables: 7
#> $ Method      <chr> "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PC…
#> $ Energy.type <chr> "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E…
#> $ Last.stage  <chr> "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final"…
#> $ Country     <chr> "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GHA", "GH…
#> $ Year        <dbl> 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971, 1971, 2000, 2000, 2000, 2000…
#> $ matname     <chr> "R", "U_EIOU", "U_excl_EIOU", "V", "Y", "R", "U_EIOU…
#> $ matval      <list> [<matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[4 x 3]>,…
class(Tidy_PSUT$matval[[1]])
#> [1] "matrix"
Tidy_PSUT$matval[[1]]
#>                                    Hydro Primary solid biofuels
#> Resources (Hydro)                    250                      0
#> Resources (Primary solid biofuels)     0                   2088
#> attr(,"rowtype")
#> [1] "Industry"
#> attr(,"coltype")
#> [1] "Product"

    Generate S_units matrices (extract_S_units_from_tidy())

    A matrix of Products and Units can be obtained from a tidy IEA data frame with the extract_S_units_from_tidy() function.

    S_units_df <- load_tidy_iea_df() %>% 
  extract_S_units_from_tidy()
S_units_df %>% 
  glimpse()
#> Observations: 4
#> Variables: 6
#> $ Method      <chr> "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM"
#> $ Last.stage  <chr> "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final"
#> $ Country     <chr> "GHA", "GHA", "ZAF", "ZAF"
#> $ Year        <dbl> 1971, 2000, 1971, 2000
#> $ Energy.type <chr> "E", "E", "E", "E"
#> $ S_units     <list> [<matrix[14 x 1]>, <matrix[16 x 1]>, <matrix[21 x 1…
S_units_df$S_units[[1]]
#>                                       ktoe
#> Aviation gasoline                        1
#> Charcoal                                 1
#> Crude oil                                1
#> Electricity                              1
#> Fuel oil                                 1
#> Gas/diesel oil excl. biofuels            1
#> Hydro                                    1
#> Kerosene type jet fuel excl. biofuels    1
#> Liquefied petroleum gases (LPG)          1
#> Lubricants                               1
#> Motor gasoline excl. biofuels            1
#> Other kerosene                           1
#> Primary solid biofuels                   1
#> Refinery gas                             1
#> attr(,"rowtype")
#> [1] "Product"
#> attr(,"coltype")
#> [1] "Unit"

    Putting it all together (prep_psut())

    prep_psut() is a convenience function. It converts a tidy IEA data frame that has gone through specify_all() into a PSUT data frame by collapsing the IEA data into PSUT matrices (R, U, V, and Y).

    This function bundles several others: 1. add_psut_matnames() 2. add_row_col_meta() 3. collapse_to_tidy_psut()

    Furthermore, it extracts S_units matrices using extract_S_units_from_tidy() and adds those matrices to the data frame.

    Simple <- load_tidy_iea_df() %>% 
  specify_all() %>% 
  prep_psut()
S_units <- load_tidy_iea_df() %>% 
  extract_S_units_from_tidy()
Complicated <- load_tidy_iea_df() %>% 
  specify_all() %>% 
  add_psut_matnames() %>% 
  add_row_col_meta() %>% 
  collapse_to_tidy_psut() %>% 
  spread(key = matname, value = matval) %>% 
  full_join(S_units, by = c("Method", "Energy.type", "Last.stage", 
                            "Country", "Year")) %>% 
  gather(key = matname, value = matval, R, U_EIOU, U_excl_EIOU, 
         V, Y, S_units)
# Simple and Complicated are same.
full_join(Simple %>% rename(matval_simple = matval), 
          Complicated %>% rename(matval_complicated = matval), 
          by = c("Method", "Energy.type", "Last.stage", "Country", "Year", "matname")) %>% 
  dplyr::mutate(
    same = matsbyname::equal_byname(matval_simple, matval_complicated)
  ) %>% 
  magrittr::extract2("same") %>% 
  as.logical() %>% 
  all()
#> [1] TRUE
Simple %>% 
  glimpse()
#> Observations: 24
#> Variables: 7
#> $ Method      <chr> "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PC…
#> $ Energy.type <chr> "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E…
#> $ Last.stage  <chr> "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final"…
#> $ Country     <chr> "GHA", "GHA", "ZAF", "ZAF", "GHA", "GHA", "ZAF", "ZA…
#> $ Year        <dbl> 1971, 2000, 1971, 2000, 1971, 2000, 1971, 2000, 1971…
#> $ matname     <chr> "R", "R", "R", "R", "U_EIOU", "U_EIOU", "U_EIOU", "U…
#> $ matval      <list> [<matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[3 x 3]>,…
# U_EIOU for Ghana in 1971
Simple$matval[[5]]
#>              Main activity producer electricity plants Oil refineries
#> Electricity                                          2              0
#> Refinery gas                                         0             20
#> attr(,"rowtype")
#> [1] "Product"
#> attr(,"coltype")
#> [1] "Industry"

    Conclusion

    Taken together, the functions in this package make it possible to prepare IEA extended energy balance data for use with PSUT analysis techniques. A sequence of three function calls are all that is required.

    Tidy_PSUT_mats <- load_tidy_iea_df() %>% 
  specify_all() %>% 
  prep_psut()
Tidy_PSUT_mats %>% 
  glimpse()
#> Observations: 24
#> Variables: 7
#> $ Method      <chr> "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PC…
#> $ Energy.type <chr> "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E", "E…
#> $ Last.stage  <chr> "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final"…
#> $ Country     <chr> "GHA", "GHA", "ZAF", "ZAF", "GHA", "GHA", "ZAF", "ZA…
#> $ Year        <dbl> 1971, 2000, 1971, 2000, 1971, 2000, 1971, 2000, 1971…
#> $ matname     <chr> "R", "R", "R", "R", "U_EIOU", "U_EIOU", "U_EIOU", "U…
#> $ matval      <list> [<matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[3 x 3]>,…

    If calculations are to be performed, the matrices can be spread so that each matrix is in its own column.

    Tidy_PSUT_mats %>% 
  spread(key = matname, value = matval) %>% 
  glimpse()
#> Observations: 4
#> Variables: 11
#> $ Method      <chr> "PCM", "PCM", "PCM", "PCM"
#> $ Energy.type <chr> "E", "E", "E", "E"
#> $ Last.stage  <chr> "Final", "Final", "Final", "Final"
#> $ Country     <chr> "GHA", "GHA", "ZAF", "ZAF"
#> $ Year        <dbl> 1971, 2000, 1971, 2000
#> $ R           <list> [<matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[3 x 3]>,…
#> $ S_units     <list> [<matrix[14 x 1]>, <matrix[16 x 1]>, <matrix[21 x 1…
#> $ U_EIOU      <list> [<matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[2 x 2]>, <matrix[2 x 3]>,…
#> $ U_excl_EIOU <list> [<matrix[4 x 3]>, <matrix[3 x 3]>, <matrix[6 x 10]>…
#> $ V           <list> [<matrix[10 x 12]>, <matrix[14 x 14]>, <matrix[13 x…
#> $ Y           <list> [<matrix[12 x 21]>, <matrix[13 x 20]>, <matrix[18 x…
